items.title: Can Tanzania's opposition challenge Samia Suluhu Hassan's 97% victory? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Tanzania's President Samia Suluhu Hassan has received an election winner certificate from the country's electoral authorities - an offical and public acknowledgement of an election victory that has proven controversial. 

At the ceremony in the adminstrative capital Dodoma, Hassan said it's time to unite the country. The electoral commission said she won around 97% of the vote. The elections had been marred by deadly violence. Demonstrators took to the streets to protest the exclusion of Hassan's main challengers. The opposition says hundreds of people were killed by police in the unrest. The government denies use of excessive force.

Deogratias Munishi speaks for Tanzania's main opposition party Chadema, which was barred from the election. He talks to DW from Nairobi, Kenya, to share his take on the president's 97% election victory. 

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Sudan conflict: What are other countries' interests? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Thousands of civilians are feared trapped in the Sudanese city of el-Fasher, and in imminent danger, after paramilitary Rapid Support Forces seized the city last Sunday. 

German Foreign Minister Johann Wadephul has described the situation as 'absolutely apocalyptic'. Survivors who fled and reached the town of Tawila about 70 kilometers away spoke of mass killings, including of children, sexual violence, beatings and robberies. The UN says more than 65,000 people have fled el-Fasher, but tens of thousands remain.

00:00 Mass atrocities in el-Fasher, Sudan 
00:49 Mary Brace, Nonviolent Peaceforce in Tawila, Sudan 
02:29 Are people actually safe in Tawila?
04:07 Hamid Khalafallah, Sudan researcher & policy analyst 
04:24 How are other countries involved in the Sudan conflict? 
08:20 Christian Lindmeier, WHO

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: New Grand Egyptian Museum to exhibit millennia of cultural history | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Many of Egypt's historic artifacts are found in museums outside the country, but those within the country are about to be displayed in its new Grand Egyptian Museum. The museum fully opens its doors next week. 

One of Egypt's world-famous artifacts outside of the country has been on display for over a century in Germany's capital Berlin.  
German archeologists found the bust of ancient Egyptian Queen Nefertiti in 1912 and took it from Egypt to Germany. Egypt wants it back. 

Sebastian Conrad, Professor of Modern History at the Freie Universität Berlin and author of "The Queen – Nefertiti's Global Career." 

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: German arms exports: No more rules? | Mapped Out
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>On paper, Germany has strict rules and human rights criteria for arms exports. So why have Matador anti-tank weapons and Sa'ar 6-class warships been ending up in Israel's war in Gaza? And why have Eurofighter Typhoon warplanes been used in the conflict in Yemen? We take a deep dive into German arms exports, the history that made them so complicated, and how Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine has turned the political tide on weapons in Germany. 

00:00 The German arms boom 
03:50 Germany's strict arms export rules 
05:19 Who can buy German weapons? 
07:30 The Eurofighter Typhoon in the Yemen war 
08:27Building stability in the Middle East? 
10:36 The Israel exception 
12:36 German arms in Gaza 
16:06 The future of German arms exports 

#mappedout

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Serbians gather to commemorate Novi Sad tragedy | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>Thousands across Serbia are set to join a rally in Novi Sad in the coming hours, to mark one year since a fatal railway station roof collapse. Protests in late 2024 called for accountability for the tragedy...and eventually led to the collapse of the federal government. Demonstrators today will honor the 16 people who died in the accident, but will also call for more transparency, and indeed, snap elections.  


For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: France is angry at its politicians — especially President Macron | Focus on Europe
items.author: DW News
items.content:
<article>French citizens voice growing frustration over rising living costs and political instability. In Lille, activists like Martine and Yolaine protest for change, struggling to survive on low incomes and feeling abandoned by the government. President Macron faces mounting criticism, with many calling for his resignation. As trust in politics erodes, grassroots movements and political theater emerge as new forms of resistance.

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/
